importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on Tuesday, October 21, 2025, indicating the current status and ongoing development of the Reefline project as a major environmental and cultural initiative in Miami Beach.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with the full realization of the 7-mile artificial reef occurring by around 2035, marking a long-term environmental restoration and cultural transformation effort.

keyTakeAways: Miami Beach is developing a 7-mile-long artificial reef called Reefline, combining art and marine science to restore lost coral habitats.
The reef will be made of underwater sculptures, including 22 cast concrete cars and 57 giant starfish, designed to support coral growth and become living ecosystems.
Colin Foord, a coral researcher and founder of Coral Morphologic, is responsible for cultivating and transplanting over 2,000 soft coral specimens that will grow to 6 feet tall.
The project is funded in part by a $5 million city bond approved by voters and aims to raise an additional $6 million to fund the first phase.
Artistic director Ximena Caminos, originally from Argentina, is a cultural placemaker who uses art to revitalize communities, and she views Reefline as a form of public housing for fish.
Reefline will be located about 15 to 20 feet underwater, 700 feet off Miami Beach, making it accessible to swimmers without boats.
The project is restoring a historic coral reef that was lost in the 1970s due to beach sand replenishment.
Resilient, locally collected corals will be used to withstand ocean warming and disease, ensuring long-term sustainability.
The project will include an onshore marine learning center to educate the public about coral reef conservation.
Artists like Leandro Ehrlich believe the sculptures will be gradually covered by coral, transforming into living, natural ecosystems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a 7-mile-long artificial reef combining marine science and art to restore a historic coral ecosystem lost in the 1970s. Led by coral researcher Colin Foord and artistic director Ximena Caminos, the project involves growing over 2,000 soft coral specimens in a nursery and transplanting them onto underwater sculptures made from marine-grade concrete, including 22 cars and 57 starfish. The reef will be accessible to swimmers, located about 700 feet offshore and 15–20 feet deep, and will take at least a decade to complete. Funded by a $5 million city bond and supplemented by a $6 million fundraising campaign, Reefline aims to revive marine biodiversity, support ecotourism, and serve as a symbol of environmental restoration and cultural innovation in Miami Beach. The project also includes an onshore learning center to educate the public about endangered coral reefs and reflects broader goals of cultural placemaking and ecosystem resilience.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
